_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention
The facility has developed a Risk Management Program to address the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements (40 CFR Part 68).  MillerCoors is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. MillerCoors staff is highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using anhydrous ammonia and chlorine.

MillerCoors LLC facility has a long standing commitment to its workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia Refrigeration System. MillerCoors policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
MillerCoors LLC facility is located at 15801 E First Street, Irwindale, California. The facility operates an ammonia refrigeration system.  The regulated substance in use is: anhydrous ammonia for the Ammonia Refrigeration System.
The largest vessels for the ammonia refrigeration system are:
?    Two Anhydrous Ammonia Receivers =16,100 lbs each.

Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary:
Scenario Description: Per the EPA RMP Regulations, one worst case analysis has been defined for each covered process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Tab 2 of the CalARP/RMP Submittal Binder.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary:
Scenario Description: Per the EPA RMP Regulations, one alternative case release scenario was modeled.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Tab 2 of the CalARP/RMP Submittal Binder.

Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia and chlorine has

inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; MillerCoors LLC ? Irwindale, California facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  Furthermore, the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a release of a regulated substance.

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with the regulated substances include:

?    Ammonia sensors are located in the process areas (sullair room, aging and cold service)
?    Automatic/manual shutdowns in place.
?    The system has alarms and interlocks
?    The system undergoes periodic maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.

The history of the MillerCoors LLC ? Irwindale, California facility reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating the Ammonia Refrigeration System.

Accidental Release Prevention Program 
As part of the implementation of this RMP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by MillerCoors ? Irwindale, California facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The Anhydrous Ammonia Prevention Program 3 elements include:

?    Process Safety Information
?    Process Hazard Analysis
?    Operating Procedures
?    Training
?    Mechanical Integrity
?    Management of Change
?    Pre-Startup Safety Review
?    Compliance Audits
?    Incident Investigation
?    Employee Participation
?    Hot Work Permit
?    Contractors

Furthermore, key emergency response eleme

nts are addressed in the facility?s Emergency Action Plan.  See EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM below.

Five-Year Accident History 
There have been no RMP-applicable releases of ammonia at MillerCoors LLC ? Irwindale, California facility in the past five years.

Emergency Response Program 
MillerCoors LLC has filed a Hazardous Materials Business Plan with Los Angeles County Fire Department.  This plan contains information regarding mitigation, prevention and abatement of hazards, notification and evacuation of the facility, employee training, earthquake preparedness, emergency responder guidelines for ammonia releases, and procedures reporting incidents to local, state and federal agencies.  In addition, MillersCoors LLC, Irwindale, California maintains an Emergency Response Team that is trained on hazardous materials response and additional training to include incipient fires response and confined space rescue. 
The Emergency Response Program at MillerCoors LLC ? Irwindale, California was last updated in February of 2009.
 
 Planned Changes To Improve Safety
A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study for MillerCoors LLC ? Irwindale, California facility was conducted on January 19th/20th of 2009 to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  A subsequent Seismic Assessment was performed in June 2009.  The planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the PHA and Seismic Assessment Reports.  

Flammables: Worst Case 
The use of flammable materials at MillerCoors LLC - Irwindale, California facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 

Flammables: Alternative Release 
The use of flammable materials at MillerCoors LLC - Irwindale, California facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.
